I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Royal Government of Bhutan (the Government), the Fact-Finding 
Mission from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) visited Bhutan from 23 September to 1 
October 2002, to formulate technical assistance (TA) for the Industrial Estate and Dry Port 
Development  Project.1  The  Mission  held  discussions  with  the  responsible  officials  of  the 
concerned agencies, including the Ministry of Finance (MOF); Department of Aid and Debt 
Management  (DADM);  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry  (MTI);  Department  of  Trade  (DOT), 
Department of Industry (DOI); Department of Employment and Labor (DEL); Department of 
Revenue  and  Customs  (DRC);  the  National  Environmental  Commission  (NEC);  the  City 
Corporation of Phuentsholing; and the Bhutan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (BCCI), 
including representatives from the private sector. This TA was developed on the basis of 
understandings reached during the Mission. An initial poverty and social assessment for the 
project is included in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bhutan is a landlocked country in the Eastern Himalayas, covering approximately 46,500 
square kilometers of mostly mountainous terrain. The population of Bhutan in 2000 was 677,934 
with a growth rate of 2.5%. Per capita gross national product in 2001 was $673.  
 
3.  After a long history of government led-development, Bhutan's economy opened up to the 
private sector in the 1980s. Since then, the economy has steadily  transformed, with rapid 
growth  of  the  urban  centers,  the  development  of  basic  infrastructure  services,  and  the 
development of a prolific hydropower sector. In mid-2001, Bhutan had over 12,878 licensed 
industrial businesses and 138 registered companies operating in a wide range of industries. 
However, reflecting the early stage of private sector development and the size of the overall 
economy, roughly 80% of all firms in the country are cottage industries (with less than Nu1 
million invested capital).  
 
4.  The Government is increasingly looking at the private sector as the main engine for 
economic development, and as the vehicle to generate employment opportunities for the rapidly 
growing number of educated Bhutanese youth. Reflecting this thrust, Bhutan's Ninth Plan 
(2002–2007), launched in July 2002, has established private sector development as one of the 
Government's strategic focus areas. As part of the Government's effort to stimulate private– 
sector-led growth in the economy, two key initiatives have been given highest priority: (i) the 
construction of a new dry port near the Indian border in Phuentsholing, and (ii) the development 
of  a  new  107  hectare  industrial  estate  in  Pasakha  (approximately  14  kilometers  from 
Phuentsholing).  
 
5.  Bhutan depends heavily on  trade with India, the source of about 85% of Bhutan's 
international  trade.  In  terms  of  volume,  trade  with  India  totaled  625,529  tons  in  1997.  
Phuentsholing, in the southwest of Bhutan, is the transit point for about 81% of Bhutan’s 
international trade. The total volume of cargo imported through Phuentsholing in 1997 was 
estimated at 600,000 tons. However, due to the limited road infrastructure and cargo handling 
capacity within Bhutan, virtually all cargo is transported in 3-4 ton trucks. There are significant 
inefficiencies due to breakage, pilferage, loading and unloading costs, etc., caused by the need 
transport cargo in small consignments. Containerized cargo, imported from countries other than 
India, is typically cleared in Kolkata (a major port in eastern India) and then transported to 
Bhutan. A United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) study estimated the total port

clearance time at 5 days on average in 1999, due to inefficiencies in handling and customs 
procedures.  
 
6.  For Bhutan, a dry port facility equipped with appropriate cargo handling and storage 
facilities under customs control with associated capabilities for clearing and forwarding goods, 
warehousing, transshipment, and transit, is essential to facilitate cross-border trade. This type of 
port will provide the same facilities as a seaport but from a land-locked location. A dry port, 
together with efficient customs clearance procedures, will substantially reduce transaction time 
at the Bhutan-India gate in Phuentsholing, and at the Kolkata port. Both the Government and 
the  private  sector  of  Bhutan  place  great  priority  on  the  development  of  a  dry  port  in 
Phuentsholing to increase trade with India and other countries. The South Asia Subregional 
Economic Cooperation (SASEC) working group, financed by ADB, has also strongly endorsed 
such a development as a high priority investment for the region. The Government has identified 
a 2.9 hectare site near the Bhutan-India gate for the project.  
 
7.  Industrial development in Bhutan is severely constrained by a lack of industrial sites with 
basic infrastructure. It is practically impossible for individual industries to bear the costs of 
infrastructure development, given the high construction costs associated with the difficult terrain 
and poor access. Recognizing this constraint, the Government, in 2000, identified five sites for 
development into industrial estates in strategic locations, of which two have been prioritized for 
development during the Ninth Plan Period. Among them is a 107 hectare site acquired by the 
Government at Pasakha, strategically located 14 kilometers from Phuentsholing, along the new 
Thimphu-Phuentsholing highway that is under construction.  
 
8.  Because of its proximity to India, Bhutan's principal trading partner, Phuentsholing has 
developed as one of the primary industrial nodes in the country. At present, there is a 25 
hectare industrial estate in Phuentsholing, which is fully occupied. Several other industries 
ranging from cement manufacturing, to wood products, to carbonated beverages, are in and 
around Phuentsholing. However, the limited availability of reasonably flat, developable, and 
serviced land has stalled the development of Phuentsholing's industrial sector. Initial market 
surveys demonstrate sufficient demand from the private sector for the industrial estate at 
Pasakha. The project will stimulate industrial investment and lead to reduced poverty and 
increased economic growth in Bhutan.  
  
9.  For the industrial estate and the dry port to be operationally viable, the Government 
needs  to  create  the  required  environment  and  attract  private  entrepreneurs  to  establish 
operations at the two project sites. This will require an appropriate legal framework and clear 
and  transparent  rules  and  regulations  to  support  market-oriented  industrial  and  trade 
development in line with national objectives. Government regulations and business practices 
need to be systematized in a structured, phased, and consistent manner to enable the private 
sector to operate effectively.  Development responsibilities for the trade and industry sectors 
rest with MTI. Within MTI, DOI assumes the administrative responsibilities and is responsible for 
formulating development plans and establishing the appropriate legal framework to promote the 
industrial  sector,  including  small-scale  industrial  activities.  Similarly,  DOT,  within  MTI,  is 
responsible for developing Bhutan’s trade sector and the regulatory and administrative systems 
for domestic commercial activities and cross-border trade. DOT is also responsible for preparing 
the economy and the country’s trade and industrial sectors for Bhutan’s integration into the 
regional  and  global  economy  and  later  into  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO).  The 
responsibility for developing the industrial estates will rest with DOI while that of the dry port will 
be with DOT.

3
10.  At present, the industrial sector is operating under the General Guidelines for Industrial 
and Commercial Ventures in Bhutan, 1997. However, the country does not have an established 
legal framework or supporting rules and regulations for the sector. A draft business licensing act 
has been prepared and is scheduled for legislation by June 2003. Under the provisions of the 
proposed act, MTI will need to consolidate and frame rules and regulations for business 
activities in Bhutan. Bhutan's Foreign Investment Policy has recently been endorsed by the 
Coordination Committee of the Council of Ministers and will form the guidelines for foreign 
investment until it is legislated.  
 
11.  All import and export activities involving cross-border trade are currently governed by the 
Sales Tax, Customs, and Excise Act (2000), and related regulations framed in 2001. Bhutan 
enjoys a tariff free trade agreement with India, which is due to expire in 2005. The rules and 
regulations must be revised to streamline cross-border trade operations. The draft export import 
policy may also need to be refined.  
 
12.  Environmental compliance guidelines have been framed for some sectors, including 
industry,  with  ADB  support.  The  Environmental  Assessment  Act  (2000),  together with the 
regulations  issued  by  the  National  Environment  Commission,  provides  the  basis  for 
environmental clearance of development projects. The draft labor administration policy2 is 
expected to be approved by the Cabinet at the soonest possible. A draft employment and labor 
act is being prepared for legislation in 2004 (footnote 2), but some rules and regulations have 
been framed for the interim period. The draft acts, rules, and regulations related to environment 
and labor policy may need to be reviewed, and potential issues identified, to establish the 
viability of the proposed dry port and industrial estate.  
 
13.  In addition to the economic need and justification for Bhutan, the development of the 
new industrial estate and dry port is expected to provide economic benefits to India. Of the 
approximately 60,000 people currently formally employed in Bhutan, approximately 50% are 
foreign nationals, mostly from India. Due to the lower cost and higher skill levels of labor from 
India, this trend is likely to continue in the short term. Increased industrial activity and cross-
border trade through the industrial estates and dry port will lead to increased (i) demand for 
skilled labor from India, (ii) demand for raw materials from India for industrial production, (iii) 
freight movement between India and Bhutan, and (iv) throughput at Kolkata port.  
 
14.  ADB is the only international development agency currently active in the trade and 
industry sectors of Bhutan.3 The Government is fully committed to the development of the dry 
port and industrial estate, and has strong support for the effort from the private sector.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
15.  The primary purpose of the TA is to assist the Government in developing the proposed 
industrial estate and dry port in the Phuentsholing region. The TA will also help the government 
create the required environment by establishing an appropriate legal framework and clear and 
transparent rules and regulations. The final output of the TA will provide the basis for a 
subsequent ADB investment in both the industrial estate and the dry port, which, together with 
associated policy reforms, will facilitate subregional economic cooperation.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA will have three distinct, yet interrelated components: (i) the development of the 
industrial estates, (ii) development of the dry port, and (iii) analysis of the policy and regulatory 
environment in the trade and industrial sectors.  
 
17.  To determine the feasibility of the industrial estates, the TA will (i) assess the current and 
projected land and infrastructure needs of the industries to be developed in the industrial 
estates; (ii) develop the design, master plan, and layout for the industrial estates and associated 
infrastructure; (iii) conduct demand assessments, projections, and willingness-to-pay surveys for 
the infrastructure services to be developed at the industrial estate sites; (iv) conduct an initial 
environmental  examination  and  social  analysis  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  guidelines  and 
recommend appropriate mitigation measures where necessary; and (v) carry out economic and 
financial analysis for the project.  
 
18.  The feasibility assessment and design of the dry port will (i) forecast international trade 
cargo traffic flows for 20 years via Phuentsholing; (ii) identify the required common infrastructure 
for the dry port; (iii) prepare a layout plan for the dry port and recommend feasible access road 
alignments; (iv) recommend improved customs clearance and documentation procedures; (v) 
prepare an initial environmental examination and social analysis in accordance with the ADB’s 
guidelines and recommend mitigation measures where necessary; and (vi) carry out economic 
and financial analysis for the Project. 
   
19.  The assessment of the regulatory environment will (i) review the policies and guidelines 
related  to  the  trade  and  industry  sectors  to  identify  critical  constraints  to  private  sector 
development (ii) help to establish an appropriate legal framework and recommend rules and 
regulations  to  support  private  sector  growth  (iii)  establish  management  authorities  for  the 
operations and maintenance of the industrial estate and dry port and (iv) establish clear and 
transparent procedures for private sector participation in the operations of the two facilities.  
 
20.  All activities will be carried out in close collaboration with pertinent Government agencies 
and the private sector. An effort will also be made to create strong linkage between ADB's 
education and skills development projects4, especially with regard to the types of industries to 
be promoted in the industrial estate. Descriptions of the activities to be carried out during the TA 
are included in the outline terms of reference for consulting services in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $825,000 equivalent of which $599,000 will be 
foreign exchange costs, and $226,000 equivalent will be local currency costs.  ADB will finance 
$700,000 equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange costs and $101,000 equivalent 
in  local  currency  costs.  The  remaining  $125,000  equivalent  will  be  contributed  by  the 
Government  and  will  include  office  accommodation,  remuneration  of  counterpart  staff, 
transportation, surveys, and workshops. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
program. The Government has been informed that ADB’s financing of the TA does not commit 
ADB to financing a subsequent loan project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
shown in Appendix 3.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  MTI will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Implementing Agency will be the Policy 
and Planning Division within MTI. MTI will set up a TA implementing unit, appoint a manager for 
the  unit,  and  provide  office  space,  furniture,  equipment,  and  counterpart  staff  for  the  TA 
consultants as necessary. DOT and DOI will provide counterpart technical staff to the TA 
consultants as required. The Government will set up a technical assistance steering committee 
(TASC), under the chairmanship of the director general, DADM, to periodically review progress 
of the TA and resolve any issues that may arise. The TASC will meet at least once every 2 
months. In addition to DADM, the TASC will include representatives from DEL, DOI, DOT, DRC, 
MTI, NEC, Ministry of Communications, National Technical Training Authority, and others as 
necessary. All representatives in the TASC will be at least director level officials. 
 
23.  The TA will be carried out over 6 months, beginning around June 2003. The consulting 
team will include nine international  consultants (23 person-months total) and six domestic 
consultants (13 person-months total). All consultants will be selected and engaged through a 
firm following ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The simplified technical proposal format 
and the quality-and cost-based selection method will be used.  
 
24.  The  consultants  will  submit  short  monthly  progress  reports,  summarizing  project 
activities, issues, and constraints, throughout the duration of the TA. In addition, four major 
reports will be submitted. An inception report will be submitted no later than 3 weeks after 
fielding of the consultants. A midterm report will be submitted 3 months after TA inception, and a 
draft final report will be submitted 5 months after inception. The Government and ADB will 
provide comments on the draft final report. The final report will be submitted within 3 weeks after 
receiving comments from the review. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of Bhutan for preparing the  Industrial Estate and Dry Port Development Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. The technical assistance, initially financed as a grant, will be 
subject to the reimbursement arrangements set forth in Technical Assistance Operations5 and 
Streamlining of Technical Assistance Operations.6 If the technical assistance results in an ADB 
loan, ADB may charge against the loan, and recover from it, the portion of the balance that 
exceeds $250,000 equivalent.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
 
The  industrial  estate  component  of  the  proposed  Project  will  provide  the  basic  infrastructure  and  operations 
management assistance to stimulate the development of large industries, as well as small and medium enterprises. 
The industrial estate, combined with possible revisions  to pertinent labor and industrial policies, is expected to 
generate many jobs that could absorb the rapidly increasing number of Bhutanese school leavers. The review of the 
policy environment will ensure maximum use of Bhutanese labor in all facilities, that women have equal access to 
opportunities for employment and investment, and that workers' social needs are fully taken into consideration. 
Besides generating employment, development of the industrial estate will result in increased availability of lower cost 
domestically produced goods throughout Bhutan. 
 
The dry port component of the project, combined with streamlined customs and freight handling procedures between 
Phuentsholing and Kolkata, is expected to increase the volume of international trade. The increased efficiency in 
cargo handling will also result in significant savings to importers, which will in turn be passed on to consumers as the 
prices of imported goods are likely to fall. Improvements to customs procedures will most likely improve the collection 
efficiency of customs duties as well.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consulting team will comprise nine international and six domestic consultants. Each 
consultant is required to work collectively with the team in developing all outputs. The specific 
technical  tasks  associated  with  each  consultant  are  outlined  here,  and  the  required 
qualifications for each consultant are indicated in Supplementary Appendix A. The team leader 
and Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer, however, may augment the tasks outlined 
as required to comply with ADB guidelines and procedures, and to improve the quality of the 
overall Project. The tasks are to be carried out in close cooperation with the Government, and 
extensive consultation is needed to ensure transfer of knowledge and full ownership of the 
processes and documents by the concerned government agencies. 
 
A.  Industrial Estate and Dry Port Planner and Team Leader  
(international, 4 person- months) 
 
2.  The team leader, will organize and manage the consulting team and coordinate the 
overall technical assistance (TA). He or she will coordinate the preparation of all documentation 
required  by  ADB  guidelines  and  the  ADB  project  officer  to  develop  the  report  and 
recommendation of the President document for the ensuing loan, including (i) a detailed project 
logical framework; (ii) project performance monitoring and evaluation arrangements, including 
baseline  data;  and  (iii)  an  assessment  of  the  detailed  procurement  and  implementation 
arrangements.  The  team  leader  will  be  accountable  for  the  quality  and  timeliness  of  all 
deliverables, and will ensure that all components are clearly and concisely documented to the 
full satisfaction of the ADB project team. The team leader will also be responsible for ensuring 
that the proposed investment that will be prepared through the TA is complete, cohesive, 
economically  and  financially  viable,  and  in  full  compliance  with  all  pertinent  ADB  and 
Government policies and guidelines.  
 
3.  Specific tasks related to the industrial estate will include the following: 
 
(i)  Assess the current and projected land and infrastructure needs of the industries 
to be developed in the industrial estate; the land requirements for all necessary 
infrastructure and support facilities; and the willingness to pay for the water 
supply,  sanitation,  power  supply,  solid  waste  management,  and  other 
infrastructure services to be developed at the site. This assessment will focus on 
the projected mix of industries at the site during the first 10 years of operation.  
(ii)  Develop a detailed structural master plan for the industrial estate, which clearly 
defines  the  infrastructure  to  be  provided  by  the  Government,  and  the  land 
allocation strategy. The plan should consider all projected land requirements, 
flexibility and efficiency in land allocation, topography, access requirements, and 
necessary land allocation for common infrastructure and amenities. The plan 
should  clearly  define  a  phasing  strategy,  based  on  realistic  projections  of 
demand. The objective is to finance the infrastructure necessary to make the first 
phase of the industrial estate operational. Therefore, the phasing strategy and 
planning effort must incorporate all cost and technical data and make realistic 
plans for a first phase that can be completely financed with the funds available.  
 
4.  Work related to the dry port will include the following: 
 
(i)  Carry out a 20 year traffic forecast for international trade cargo passing through 
Phuentsholing. Include (a) export cargo to India, (b) import cargo from India, (c) 
export cargo to third countries through Kolkata Port, and (d) import cargo from 
third  countries  through  Kolkata  Port.  The  traffic  forecast  should  include  the

volume of cargo in weight and size, and number of vehicles used to transport the 
cargo in Bhutan and India.  
(ii)  Examine if the existing access road to the dry port is sufficient given the number 
and types of vehicles that will be used. Recommend options for improving access 
to  the  site,  if  necessary,  through  traffic  regulations  or  the  identification  of 
alternative routes.  
(iii)  Identify  required  facilities  including  stacking  yard,  parking  area,  warehouses, 
office buildings, lighting systems, and equipment for handling cargo, particularly 
for containers. Prepare a layout plan of the dry port and the access road, and its 
alternatives if identified. Prepare an implementation schedule for civil works and 
provision of equipment. 
 
B.  Economist and Financial Analyst (international, 3 person-months) 
 
(i)  Guide  the  overall  development  of  the  project  and  work  closely  with  each 
consultant on the team to ensure that each component is developed to meet all 
pertinent  ADB  and  Government  criteria  and  guidelines.  Consider  potential 
synergies with other ADB projects, as well as initiatives by the Government and 
other development agencies.  
(ii)  Based  on  assessments  of  the  overall  financial  envelope  of  the  project, 
recommend lease rates for the land, as well as tariff structures for infrastructure 
and management services to be provided at the industrial estate. All efforts must 
be  made  to  develop  all  facilities  on  a  full  cost-recovery  basis.  Government 
subsidies should only be considered as a last option.  
(iii)  In coordination with the overall team, ensure that all proposed solutions are 
affordable to the Government and the private sector, economically and financially 
sound, and sustainable given the resource constraints in the country. Pay close 
attention to the suitability of the technology options and associated costs to the 
context of Bhutan. 
(iv)  In  coordination  with  the  overall  team,  develop  detailed  cost  estimates  and 
financing  plans;  identify  and  estimate  financial  benefits  of  the  dry  port  and 
industrial estate operations; and conduct financial and economic analysis for 
each project component and for the overall project. The analyses will quantify 
project  benefits  such  as  price  reductions  of  imported  goods  due  to  lower 
transportation costs, and increased availability of locally manufactured goods, 
increased  employment  opportunities  at  various  skill  levels.  Financial  and 
economic analyses will be performed in accordance with the ADB’s Guidelines 
for the Financial Management and Governance of Investment Projects Financed 
by the Asian Development Bank and Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of 
Projects. The economic analysis should include a quantitative analysis of risk, in 
line with ADB's Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis 
of Projects. 
(v)  Prepare a poverty impact assessment that illustrates the impact of the dry port 
and industrial estate on poverty reduction, in accordance with ADB's Handbook 
on Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. A 
poverty impact ratio of the project should also be calculated. The assessment will 
include the estimated distribution of project benefits between poor and non-poor, 
and the project's potential role in reducing the number of households that are 
below  the  poverty  line.  Also  conduct  a  distribution  analysis,  which  shows 
distribution of project benefits (a) between stakeholders within Bhutan, and (b) 
between Bhutan and India.

C.  Civil Engineer and Infrastructure Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
(i)  Work closely with the industrial estate planner to assess the infrastructure needs 
for each phase of the industrial estate. Based on this assessment, and careful 
evaluation  of  site-specific  conditions,  develop  schematic  designs  and 
specifications for the water supply, drainage, power, and road systems to be 
developed during the first phase of the project.  
(ii)  Develop the schematic design and specifications for the least-cost and most 
sustainable methods for managing wastewater and solid waste produced at the 
industrial estate. The waste management systems should consider projections of 
the types of industries and associated waste products that are likely to be 
produced.  
(iii)  Ensure that all infrastructure systems are scaleable, to meet the demands for 
future phases of development. Technical options must always be developed on a 
least-cost basis, and should be sustainable given the environmental, technical, 
and resource constraints in Bhutan.  
 
D.  Environment Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
(i)  Examine all environmental acts, guidelines, and procedures related to industrial 
development put in place by the Government and assess whether any additional 
safeguards are necessary to ensure environmentally friendly development of the 
industrial  estate.  Recommend  environmental  standards  and  monitoring  and 
enforcement mechanisms.  
(ii)  Review and compile all environmental baseline data pertinent to the project sites, 
including physical and ecological resources as well as socioeconomic and cultural 
components. Screen potential environmental impacts and recommend appropriate 
mitigation measures where necessary.  
(iii)  Prepare an initial environmental examination and its summary for all proposed 
project components, and assess whether a full environmental impact assessment 
will be required. All environmental assessments and examinations should be 
conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected 
Infrastructure Projects (1993) and  Environmental Assessment Requirements of 
the Asian Development Bank (1998). 
 
E.  Industrial and Trade Policy Specialist (international, 3.5 person-months) 
 
(i)  Review the policy environment of the industrial sector, including the present 
Government  policy  and  strategy.  Identify  the  main  constrains  to  industrial 
development in the country, and recommend policy measures necessary to ease 
constraints identified. 
(ii)  Working closely with the legal specialist, review the guidelines for industrial and 
commercial ventures and the draft business licensing act, and help establish the 
appropriate legal framework and rules and regulations to support market-oriented 
industrial development in line with national objectives. 
(iii)  Work closely with the legal specialist to examine the existing and proposed labor 
policy and regulations regarding  conditions  on  employment  and  employment 
conditions,  including  wage  structures  covering  the  private  sector  and  their 
implications on the proposed industrial estate and dry port.  
(iv)  Assess  the  adequacy  of  direct  and  indirect  incentives  currently  in  place  to 
promote industrial development. Recommend additional incentives that could 
stimulate private sector interest in the proposed industrial estate in Pasakha.  
(v)  Identify potential small- and medium-size industries that can be accommodated 
within the industrial estate. Examine the constraints faced by small and medium

Appendix 2  11 
enterprises in Bhutan, and identify incentive mechanisms that would stimulate 
them to take advantage of the proposed industrial estate.  
(vi)  Review the policy, regulatory framework, and rules and regulations affecting 
international trade, including export and import licensing, export promotion, and 
customs and tariff structures, and assess their impact on the overall trade volume 
of Bhutan. Identify key constraints, and recommend remedial measures where 
appropriate.  
(vii)  Review the acts and regulations related to direct and indirect taxes, including the 
Sales Tax, Customs, and Excise Act, 2000, and assess their impact on industries 
engaged in international trade. Identify key constraints and recommend remedial 
measures where appropriate.  
(viii)  Review  and  suggest  improvements  on  the  draft  export  import  policy  and 
determine the need, if any, for a foreign trade act. 
(ix)  Prepare a realistic time-bound action plan for implementing all the necessary 
reforms identified.  
 
F.  Institutional Development Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
(i)  Assist  the  Government  in  establishing  an  industrial  estates  management 
authority (IEMA) and a dry ports management authority (DPMA). Review the 
organizational structures and management systems of similar facilities in other 
countries, and identify roles and responsibilities for IEMA and DPMA. Identify 
short-, medium-, and long-term training needs related to these two authorities, 
and organize site visits to similar facilities in the region as appropriate.  
(ii)  Prepare management plans for the industrial estate and dry port, emphasizing 
financial management and operational efficiency. The management plans should 
include  financial  management  guidelines,  marketing  strategies,  accounting 
systems,  operations  and  maintenance  programs,  environmental  monitoring 
programs, and work plans for other specific tasks.  
(iii)  Assess the human, technical, and financial resources required to successfully 
operate the dry port and industrial estate. Based on the assessment, develop 
organizational structures and personnel requirements for IEMA and DPMA.  
(iv)  Identify specific operations within the industrial estate and dry port that could be 
operated  by  the  private  sector.  Such  activities  could  include  cargo-handling 
operations at the dry port, solid waste management systems and water supply 
and sanitation systems at the industrial estate, etc.  Formulate policies and 
appropriate processes to facilitate private sector participation in these activities in 
a transparent and competitive manner.     
(v)  Define the potential role of Department of Employment and Labor (DEL), and the 
necessary  linkage  between  DEL  and  the  IEMA  and  DPMA,  during  both 
construction and operating phases of the project.  
 
G.  Customs Operation Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months) 
 
(i)  Assess the current systems and procedures for customs clearance (Indian and 
Bhutanese)  at  the  Phuentsholing  border  and  Kolkata  port.  Identify  ways  to 
streamline operations and reduce the transaction time.  
(ii)  Evaluate the Bhutan Automatic Customs System, and recommend improvements 
to it in terms of expanding access to private sector freight forwarders, exporters, 
and shipping agents using electronic data interchange systems.   
(iii)  Recommend standardized documentation and simplified procedures that could 
be incorporated into both Bhutanese and Indian custom clearance systems. Also 
explore the possibility of digitally linking both systems.

H.  Legal Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
(i)  Work  closely  with  the  industrial  and  trade  policy  specialist  and  review  and 
recommend revisions to existing policies, acts, and rules and regulations related 
to the trade and industry sectors.  
(ii)  Work closely with the industry and trade specialist to review the existing and 
proposed labor policies and their implications for the proposed industrial estate 
and dry port. 
(iii)  Work  closely  with  the  institutional  development  specialist  and  formulate 
legislation and guidelines related to the establishment and operation of IEMA and 
DPMA.  The  guidelines  should  include,  but  not  be  limited  to,  establishing 
procedures for evaluating bids, and preparing contract documents for engaging 
the private sector for specific operations (such as cargo handling) and land and 
equipment leasing arrangements.  
(iv)  Work closely with the industry and trade policy specialist and examine the need 
for a regulatory authority for the dry port operations. 
(v)  Work closely with the environment specialist and develop revisions to existing 
government environmental regulations as required.  
 
I.  Resettlement Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
5.  The specialist will review and document the land acquisition and resettlement activities 
related to the overall project carried out by the Government. If any further resettlement activities 
are  identified,  the  specialist  will  recommend  Government  action  needed  to  ensure  full 
compliance with ADB's guidelines on resettlement, social protection, and other pertinent social 
safeguards.  
 
J.  Social Development Specialist (domestic, 2 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will assist in all tasks defined under the terms of reference for the 
international resettlement specialist, and will develop a social assessment of the project. The 
assessment  should  include  a  socioeconomic  survey  of  potential  project  beneficiaries  and 
affected parties, and other studies as required by the social development strategy of the ADB. 
Compliance with all other pertinent ADB social policies and safeguards should also be ensured. 
 
K.  Electrical Engineer and Power Specialist (domestic, 1 person-month) 
 
7.  The specialist will assist the international civil engineer in designing the power supply 
systems for the dry port and industrial estate.   
 
L.  Other Domestic Consultants  
 
8.  Other domestic consultants will include (i) a civil engineer (2 person-months); (ii) an 
environment specialist (3 person-months); (iii) an industrial estate and dry port planner (3 
person-months); and (iv) a customs operations specialist (2 person-months). Each consultant 
will assist in tasks defined under the terms of reference for his or her international counterparts.
